questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with hypopigmented patches on her skin and silvery-white hair. She also experiences easy bruising and prolonged bleeding following minor injuries. Examination reveals reduced iris pigmentation and visual impairment. Which primary pathological mechanism contributes to the hypopigmented skin observed in this patient?

choices.text: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation in epidermal cells
Defective melanosome formation, trafficking, or transfer to keratinocytes
Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

EXPLANATION:

The given clinical scenario of a patient with symptoms of bleeding diathesis (easy bruising, prolonged bleeding following minor injuries), hypopigmentation of skin, hair & eyes with visual impairment & reduced iris pigmentation (oculocutaneous albinism), is suggestive of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS) is a rare, autosomal recessive form of oculocutaneous albinism and non-pigmented symptoms such as bleeding diathesis. 

It is caused by mutations in genes encoding components of specific protein complexes involved in lysosome biogenesis and trafficking. These mutations lead to impaired melanosome maturation and the absence of dense bodies in platelets.

Common manifestations across HPS subtypes include reduced pigmentation in the eyes, hair, and skin, along with easy bruising, bleeding tendencies, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis in severe cases.

Platelet granule defects: 
Alpha granule defect- Grey platelet syndrome
Delta granule defect- Hermansky Pudlak syndrome

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Ceroid lipofuscin accumulation is observed in abnormal lysosomes of various organs in HPS, including alveolar macrophages in the lungs, it is not primarily associated with epidermal cells in the skin.

Option B: Weibel-Palade bodies are secretory granules found in endothelial cells and are involved in regulating vascular function. Dysregulation of Weibel-Palade bodies can result in impaired hemostasis, endothelial dysfunction, and a high risk of thrombus formation.

Option D: Autophagocytosis and defective fission of large melanosomes are seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the LYST gene (lysosomal trafficking regulator/CHS 1).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with hypopigmented patches on her chest and back after recovering from a severe rash caused by contact dermatitis. The affected areas are smooth, without any scaling, itching, or scarring. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation

Explanation:

Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation can occur after any skin condition, particularly in darker skin, and is caused by decreased melanin production or transfer to keratinocytes.

 

Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation (PIH):

  • Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation refers to the loss of normal skin color, appearing as lighter patches after skin inflammation subsides.
  • It is the most frequent cause of acquired hypopigmentation.
  • Common side effect of topical corticosteroid use.
  • Darker skin types are more prone to developing PIH.
  • Factors:
    • Impaired Melanin Transfer: Inflammation can disrupt the normal process of melanin transfer from melanocytes (pigment-producing cells) to keratinocytes (skin cells).
    • Melanocyte Loss: The inflammatory process can damage or destroy melanocytes, leading to reduced melanin production.
    • Topical Corticosteroids: While effective in reducing inflammation, potent topical corticosteroids can also inhibit melanin production.
  • PIH is often reversible, especially if melanin production and transfer can be restored.
  • Treatment:
    • Avoiding triggers.
    • Protecting the skin from sun exposure , as UV radiation can worsen hypopigmentation.

 

Vitiligo (Option B) is also characterized by hypopigmented macules, it is less likely in this case because it is related to a previous inflammatory condition.

 

Pityriasis alba (Option C) typically presents as hypopigmented, slightly scaly patches on the face or upper body, often in children or young adults with a history of atopic dermatitis. It is usually characterized by mild scaling or dryness, which was not mentioned in the question.

 

Nevus depigmentosus (Option D) is a congenital, stable, hypopigmented macule that is usually present at birth and does not change in size or shape.

questions.text: A 32 y/o male presents to the clinic with progressively enlarging, hypopigmented patches on the backs of both hands. He has worked in a chemical factory for the past five years, handling various industrial solvents. Wood’s lamp examination reveals well-demarcated depigmented patches with no fluorescence. What chemical is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) p-Tertiary-butylphenol

 

Explanation:

 

  • The scenario describes a typical presentation of chemical leukoderma in the context of occupational exposure to a substituted phenol.
  • p-Tertiary-butylphenol substituted phenol is a known cause of the chemical leukoderma.

 

Chemical

Clinical Presentation

Monobenzylether of hydroquinone

Confetti-like areas of depigmentation, typically where it is applied.

4-Tertiary-butyl-catechol

Depigmentation, particularly on the hands; areas may enlarge, and new ones may appear even after contact has ceased.

Phenolic germicides

Depigmentation

Para tertiary butyl phenol

Bindi dermatitis

MBEH (mercaptobenzothiazole)

Rubber chappals dermatitis

 

Option A: Kojic acid is a skin-lightening agent used in some cosmetic products, it is not typically associated with chemical leukoderma.

 

Option B: Azelaic acid is another compound used in treating hyperpigmentation, it is not a common cause of chemical leukoderma.

 

Option D: While mercury can cause skin discoloration, it typically presents as a blue-grey or purplish pigmentation on light-exposed skin and the sclerae.

questions.text: A 32 y/o female presents with gradually progressive, well-demarcated hypopigmented patches on her face. She has a history of melasma for which she has been using a triple-combination cream containing hydroquinone, tretinoin, and a corticosteroid for the past year. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Drug induced Leukoderma

Explanation:

  • Given the patient's history of using a hydroquinone-containing cream and the clinical presentation of hypopigmented patches the most likely diagnosis is drug induced Leukoderma.

  • Topical or Intralesional Corticosteroids
  • Gefitinib (EGFR inhibitor)
  • Imatinib Mesylate (Tyrosine kinase inhibitor)
  • Pegylated Interferon (Immunomodulator)
  • Topical Imiquimod (Immunomodulator)
  • Transdermal Methylphenidate (CNS stimulant)

Localized hypopigmentation/depigmentation can be seen at the site of application.

Chemical leukoderma:

  • Develops due to exposure to certain drugs containing chemicals that have a toxic effect on melanocytes, resulting in the loss of pigment in the affected skin areas.
  • Causes: p-Tertiary-butylphenol and the monobenzylether of hydroquinone.
  • Mechanism: Selective, lethal effect on functional melanocytes
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Appearance: Well-defined areas of depigmentation on the skin. The hands, particularly the dorsal, are the most common sites due to frequent contact.
    • Progression: Depigmented areas may expand, and new lesions can appear even after ceasing contact with the causative agent.
  • Treatment:
    • Avoid contact with the identified chemical.
    • Repigmentation may occur naturally over time.

 

Option A: While vitiligo presents with depigmented patches, it is characterized by a complete absence of melanocytes and typically presents with milky-white macules.

Option C: Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation: This type of hypopigmentation occurs following skin inflammation, but it is not typically associated with the use of triple-combination creams for melasma.

Option D: Melasma is characterized by hyperpigmentation, not hypopigmentation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with bilateral uveitis, dysacousia, and poliosis. On examination, there are areas of leukoderma observed on the skin. Which syndrome is associated with the clinical presentation described?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option B

EXPLANATION: This patient with the above symptoms most likely has Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome.

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder that primarily affects melanocytes. It manifests with a range of symptoms that typically involve the eyes, ears, skin, and central nervous system.

The underlying cause of VKH syndrome is thought to be an autoimmune reaction against melanocytes. Genetic predisposition and environmental factors may contribute to the development of the condition.

The hallmark features of VKH syndrome include:

  1. Bilateral uveitis.
  2. Dysacousia.
  3. Poliosis: Depigmentation or whitening of the hair, particularly noticeable in the eyelashes, eyebrows, or scalp. This occurs due to the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes, which results in the loss of pigment production in affected hair follicles.
  4. Leukoderma: Hypopigmented patches or areas of lighter skin that arise due to the disruption of melanin production by melanocytes. These patches may appear on various parts of the body and can vary in size and distribution.

Other features include skin changes, such as vitiligo, and neurological symptoms like headaches, meningismus (meningeal irritation), meningitis or encephalitis. Ocular complications (Sunset glow appearance seen on fundus examination) may also include serous retinal detachments or optic disc swelling.

Diagnosis is typically based on clinical findings, and management involves a multidisciplinary approach, including the use of immunosuppressive medications to control inflammation and prevent disease progression. Early recognition and treatment are essential for preserving vision and minimizing complications.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Waardenburg's syndrome presents features such as dystopia canthorum/telecanthus (increased distance between medial canthi), heterochromia iridis, and hearing loss. It typically does not involve uveitis or cause leukoderma.

 

Option C: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is characterized by albinism and bleeding diathesis and may cause pulmonary fibrosis or granulomatous colitis.

Option D: Chemical leukoderma occurs due to exposure to certain chemicals and typically presents with depigmented patches on chemical exposure areas.

Common sources of chemical exposure include:

  • Germicides, insecticides, cosmetics - Eg. Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone ,Mercurials (e.g., thimerosal) & Cinnamic aldehyde (as preservatives)
  • Hair dyes, skin-lightening products - Eg. Hydroquinone
  • Rubber products, adhesives, hair dyes- Eg. Para-tertiary butylphenol
  • Clothing treated with azo dyes

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hypopigmented lesions shown below. There is no inflammation or textural changes associated with the lesions. The patient reports a family history of autoimmune diseases. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

EXPLANATION:

The clinical scenario illustrates a patient with depigmented patches on their face and neck, without inflammation or itching. This manifestation, coupled with a family history of autoimmune conditions (most commonly thyroid abnormalities), suggests the presence of vitiligo.

Vitiligo is a common acquired pigmentation disorder characterized by developing well-defined, depigmented macules on the skin.

Lesional skin biopsies reveal a loss of epidermal melanocytes. Lesions may occur in a localized or generalized distribution and coalesce into large, depigmented areas.

Wood's lamp emits ultraviolet A(UV-A) light and is particularly useful in identifying depigmented areas in patients with vitiligo. It exhibits a bright blue-white fluorescence with sharply demarcated borders.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: Dermoscopy may help differentiate evolving vitiligo patches from other hypopigmentation disorders. However, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of vitiligo.

Option B: While a skin biopsy may be performed to confirm hypopigmented or depigmented lesions with questionable aetiology, it is not routinely required to diagnose vitiligo, especially when clinical features are characteristic.

Option D: KOH wet mount is used to diagnose fungal infections, it has no role in the diagnosis of vitiligo

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was diagnosed with vitiligo with lesions as shown below. They have been stable for the past few years, with no other lesions elsewhere. What is the most likely clinical subtype of vitiligo in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acrofacial vitiligo

 

Explanation:

 

The image and clinical description suggest vitiligo lesions localised to the face, particularly around the perioral and periorbital areas, which is characteristic of acrofacial vitiligo.

Vitiligo can be classified as segmental and non-segmental types.

 

Segmental vitiligo involves depigmentation along a specific segment/dermatome with one or more white macules on one side of the body, usually not crossing the midline. It often begins during childhood or early adulthood and usually stabilizes within a year, with limited spread beyond the affected dermatome.

Non-segmental vitiligo includes:

  • Acrofacial-Affects face, head, hands, and feet, and preferably involves the perioral region and the extremities of digits

  • Mucosal- Affects the oral and genital mucosae. (Option B ruled out)

  • Generalized or Common- Often symmetrical, can affect any part of the tegument, mainly hands, fingers, face, and trauma-exposed areas. (Option D ruled out)
  • Universal- Affects 80-90% of the body surface, the most common form in adulthood. (Option C ruled out)
  • Mixed- Simultaneous involvement of segmental and non-segmental vitiligo

Poor prognostic factors of vitiligo: 

  • Long-standing disease.
  • Lesions on resistant areas like Bony prominences, non-hairy areas, mucosae, ankle wrist, elbow, lips, and genitalia.
  • Associated with Leukotrichia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with characteristic findings of Waardenburg syndrome, including wide-set eyes (hypertelorism), a broad nasal bridge, and a white forelock of hair. The child's father is also affected. What is the most likely inheritance pattern of Waardenburg syndrome in this case, and how would you counsel the parents regarding the risk of recurrence in future pregnancies?

choices.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance; 50% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
Autosomal recessive inheritance; 25% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
X-linked recessive inheritance; 25% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy
Sporadic occurrence; negligible risk of recurrence in future pregnancies

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: OPTION A

EXPLANATION:

Autosomal dominant inheritance; 50% risk of recurrence in each pregnancy.

Waardenburg syndrome (WS) is a group of genetic conditions inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. Autosomal dominant inheritance means that a child only needs to inherit one copy of the mutated gene from either parent to express the trait. This means that if one parent carries the mutated gene, there's a 50% chance of passing it on to each child. Hence, in each pregnancy where one parent carries the gene, there's a 50% risk of the child having Waardenburg syndrome.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with irregular hypopigmented macules on his forehead and anterior part of the body. Examination reveals a white forelock and V-shaped leukoderma on the mid-forehead. Small spots of hyperpigmentation are also noted within the hypopigmented lesions. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most likely responsible for the observed clinical features?

choices.text: Heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene
Autosomal dominant mutations in TERT gene
Heterozygous mutations in the SNAI2 gene
Autosomal recessive mutations in the NOLA3 gene

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of hypopigmented macules with white forelock and V-shaped leukoderma on the forehead is suggestive of piebaldism.
  • It is associated with heterozygous mutations in the KIT gene.

  • Piebaldism is a rare autosomal dominant disorder with congenital white patches that results from impairment of melanoblast migration in embryonal development.
  • The KIT gene encodes for the c-KIT protein, a receptor with tyrosine kinase activity, essential for various cellular processes, including melanocyte migration and proliferation, and throughout life.
  • When mutations occur in one allele of the KIT gene, it disrupts the normal function of c-KIT, leading to impaired melanocyte migration and proliferation.
  • This disruption leads to the formation of hypopigmented patches on the skin, which occur due to the absence of melanocytes in certain areas.
  • The forehead, chest, abdomen, and extremities are typically involved.
  • The distribution of the lesions remains for the entire life of affected individuals.

 

The TERT gene (Option B) encodes for telomerase reverse transcriptase, which plays a crucial role in maintaining telomere length and genomic stability.

  • Mutations in TERT have been associated with various conditions such as dyskeratosis congenita.
  • However, there is no established association between mutations in the TERT gene and piebaldism.

The SNAI2 gene (Option C) encodes for the zinc finger transcription factor Snail family transcriptional repressor 2 (SNAI2), also known as SLUG.

  • SNAI2 is involved in various cellular processes, including epithelial-mesenchymal transition and embryonic development.
  • There is no known association between SNAI2 mutations and piebaldism.

Autosomal recessive mutations in the NOLA3 (Option D) gene are incorrect, as piebaldism typically follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of easy bruising, recurrent nosebleeds, and progressive shortness of breath over the past few years. Physical examination reveals hypopigmentation of the skin, hair, and eyes. Upon further inquiry, the patient mentions a family history of similar symptoms in her siblings. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

EXPLANATION:

The given clinical scenario of a patient with symptoms of bleeding diathesis (easy bruising, recurrent nosebleeds), hypopigmentation of skin, hair & eyes (oculocutaneous albinism), shortness of breath, and family history of similar symptoms is suggestive of Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome.

Diagnostic evaluation involves electron microscopy of platelets to detect absent dense bodies, which serves as a standard diagnostic test. Upon platelet stimulation, dense bodies containing ADP, ATP, serotonin, calcium, and phosphate release their contents to attract other platelets.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option A: A platelet aggregation assay is not typically used to diagnose Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome (HPS). While bleeding tendencies are characteristic, the primary diagnostic test for HPS involves assessing platelet morphology rather than function.

Option B: Pulmonary function tests may aid in the diagnosis and monitoring of complications such as interstitial pulmonary fibrosis in Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome.

Option D: Genetic sequencing of HPS-associated genes can confirm the diagnosis by identifying mutations in genes associated with HPS. However, compared to the direct observation of platelet morphology, it is not always readily available or necessary for initial diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient complains of increased skin pigmentation following prolonged sun exposure. Which of the following statements regarding melanin physiology is most accurate?

choices.text: Melanocytes primarily produce eumelanin, responsible for skin pigmentation and protection against UV radiation.
Tyrosinase is an enzyme that converts tyrosine to melanin in keratinocytes.
Melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes occurs via exocytosis.
Individuals with albinism have increased melanin production due to mutations in the MC1R gene.

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option A : Melanocytes primarily produce eumelanin, responsible for skin pigmentation and protection against UV radiation.

EXPLANATION:

Melanocytes are specialized cells that produce melanin, a pigment responsible for skin colouration, hair, and eyes.

Eumelanin, along with pheomelanin, is one of the two main types of melanin produced by melanocytes. It ranges from brown to black and protects against harmful ultraviolet (UV) radiation by absorbing and scattering UV light, thereby reducing the risk of DNA damage and skin cancer.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Tyrosinase is an enzyme that converts tyrosine to melanin in keratinocytes.(Option B): Tyrosinase is a crucial enzyme in melanin synthesis, but it functions primarily within melanocytes, not keratinocytes. Tyrosinase catalyzes the conversion of the amino acid tyrosine to dopaquinone, a melanin precursor, within melanocytes' specialized melanosome organelles.

Melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes occurs via exocytosis.(Option C): Melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes typically occurs through dendricity or melanosome transfer, not exocytosis. Epidermal melanin unit=1:36. In dendritic, melanocytes extend their dendrites to transfer melanosomes directly to neighbouring keratinocytes, enhancing skin pigmentation and UV protection in the epidermis.

Individuals with albinism have increased melanin production due to mutations in the MC1R gene(Option D): Albinism is characterized by reduced or absent melanin production, leading to lighter skin, hair, and eye colouration. It is caused by genetic mutations affecting enzymes involved in melanin synthesis, such as tyrosinase or other proteins in the melanin pathway, not mutations in the MC1R gene, which is associated with the regulation of melanin synthesis and pigmentation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the dermatologist by concerned parents due to their child's extremely fair skin, white hair, and pale blue eyes. Upon examination, the dermatologist confirms the absence of melanin pigment in the child's skin, hair, and irises. The child also shows signs of photophobia and is noted to have nystagmus. Which of the following inheritance patterns is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

 

EXPLANATION:

 

The given clinical scenario of hypopigmentation of the skin and hair, ocular manifestations such as nystagmus and photophobia suggest oculocutaneous albinism. It is associated with an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by generalized hypopigmentation and ophthalmological anomalies caused by a deficiency in melanin biosynthesis with normal melanocyte count. There are seven types of OCA, all of which are associated with an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

 

There can be either failure of synthesis of tyrosinase enzyme or defect in tyrosinase activity.

Clinical features include hypopigmentation of skin, hair, and eyes and ocular findings such as photophobia (which may be prominent). Iris translucency can be demonstrated by slit-lamp examination. A characteristic finding is the misrouting of the optic nerves, consisting of an excessive crossing of the fibres in the optic chiasma, which can result in strabismus and reduced stereoscopic vision.

Note: Ocular albinism has an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with hypopigmented macules distributed along the lines of Blaschko. The lesions are asymptomatic and have been present since birth. There is no history of progression or associated symptoms. Which conditions are most likely to present with this clinical manifestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nevus Depigmentosus

Explanation:

The image and clinical description point towards Nevus depigmentosus, a non-progressive hypopigmented congenital skin disorder.

Key Clinical Features of Nevus Depigmentosus:

  • Present at or shortly after birth

  • Hypopigmented macules with irregular but well-defined margins

  • Distributed in a segmental or Blaschkoid pattern

  • Non-progressive and asymptomatic

  • No scaling, erythema, or associated systemic abnormalities

 

Vitiligo (Option B) presents with depigmented macules that may increase in size and number over time due to autoimmune destruction of melanocytes and are not restricted to dermatomal distribution.

 

Nevus anemicus (Option C) typically presents as hypopigmented macules due to persistent cutaneous vasoconstriction resulting from hypersensitivity to catecholamines that become more pronounced with rubbing or trauma. It does not follow the lines of Blaschko.

 

Piebaldism (Option D) is an autosomal dominant condition that presents with depigmented patches on the skin and a characteristic white forelock of hair. However, it is usually present at birth and does not follow the lines of Blaschko.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman develops dusky red to brown patches on her arms and legs as shown in the image below after taking a specific antibiotic for sinus infections. The patches, not painful but slightly itchy, leave hyperpigmented areas after resolving. She had a similar reaction to a same medication in the past. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option A

EXPLANATION:

In the described clinical scenario, the patient's presentation of reddish-brown macules on her hands and legs after initiating antibiotic therapy, along with a history of similar macules following the use of other medications, indicates a likely diagnosis of fixed drug eruptions.

Fixed drug eruption is a common form of drug-induced skin reaction characterized by well-defined areas of slate-brown pigmentation that persist after the acute phase. These lesions typically recur at the same site upon re-exposure to the causative drug.

A type IV hypersensitivity reaction could potentially mediate the prolonged expression of intercellular adhesion molecule 1 (ICAM-1) in keratinocytes. The slate-brown color is due to pigmented macrophages in the upper dermis.

Fixed eruptions can be triggered by a variety of drugs, including tetracyclines, NSAIDs, sulfonamides, and sedatives.

Lesions often follow an erythematous or bullous stage and can affect any skin surface, with recurrent lesions at the same sites and new areas of involvement upon repeated exposure to the drug.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation: It is a common skin condition that occurs after inflammation or injury to the skin. It is characterized by darkening of the skin in areas that have healed from conditions such as acne, eczema, or trauma. It is not caused by a specific medication.

 

Option C: Lichen planus pigmentosus: It is a rare variant of lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes. It is characterized by dark brown to greyish-blue patches on the skin, typically on sun-exposed areas such as the face, neck, and forearms.

 

Option D: Melasma is a common skin condition that causes brown or gray patches to develop on the face, typically on the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, and upper lip. It is thought to be triggered by hormonal changes and sun exposure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female on OCP presents with hyperpigmented macules on her cheeks and forehead. On examination, the lesions appear darker than the surrounding skin and have scalloped margins. There is no associated inflammation or itching. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option A

EXPLANATION:

This woman with hyperpigmented patches on her cheek and a history of OCP use most likely has melasma.

Melasma is characterized by hyperpigmented macules with scalloped or irregular margins that are darker than the surrounding areas. These patches typically appear on the face, with common locations being the cheeks, forehead, and chin. 

Etiologic factors include genetic influences, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, pregnancy, hormonal therapies (Ex-OCPs), cosmetics, and phototoxic drugs.

Sun protection with broad-spectrum sunscreen with a high SPF, wearing protective clothing, and avoiding prolonged sun exposure aim to prevent further pigmentation.

Topical hydroquinone inhibits tyrosinase, an enzyme responsible for pigment production in melanocytes, and is a common depigmenting agent. Triple combination therapy of hydroquinone, retinoid, and corticosteroid is highly effective for melasma. Chemical peels, azelaic acid, and laser therapy are other options.

OTHER OPTIONS:

Option B: Lentigo is a dark brown hyperpigmented macule occurring due to an increased number of melanocytes (function of melanocytes remains normal). They usually appear during childhood as uniformly pigmented macules, with a round or oval shape and a diameter of up to 5 mm, and increase in number with age.

Option C: Freckles are pale to dark brown macules with a poorly defined border on sun‐exposed areas of the skin. They are common during childhood and caused by the overproduction of melanin by melanocytes upon exposure to UV radiation. Hence, they appear or darken during UV exposure.

Option D: Chloasma is a hypermelanosis of sun-exposed areas that occurs during pregnancy and affects 50-70% of pregnant women. It presents similar to melasma but in pregnant women. It tends to improve spontaneously postpartum, and treatment may not be necessary.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant presents with a large, darkly pigmented lesion on their lower back. The lesion has been present since birth and has increased proportionally in size with the infant's growth. There is also the presence of hypertrichosis (excessive hair growth) within the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

Explanation:

In the above scenario, nevi are present at birth and are associated with hypertrichosis and rugosities. Congenital Melanocytic Nevus is the most likely diagnosis.

Congenital Melanocytic Nevi (CMN):

  • These are benign growths of melanocytes (pigment-producing cells), present at birth.
  • CMN arise from the neural crest, a temporary group of cells in embryonic development.
  • Characteristics:
    • A single lesion.
    • Exhibit hypertrichosis (increased hair growth) and rugosities (a wrinkled appearance).
  • Classification:
    • Congenital: Present at birth.
    • Acquired: Develop after birth.
  • Size and Malignant Potential:
    • Small to Medium CMN: Benign.
    • Large/Giant CMN (Bathing Trunk/Garment Nevi): Higher risk of developing melanoma (skin cancer).
  • Treatment: Surgical removal, laser therapy, or other therapies.

 

Mongolian spots (Option B) are typically bluish macules found in the sacral area. They tend to fade over time and are not associated with hypertrichosis.

Nevus of Ota (Option C) a bluish/slate-gray patch affecting ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve, face, eyes, oral mucosa.

Nevus Depigmentosus (Option D) presents as a single hypopigmented (lighter) macule, typically present at birth.

questions.text: A 35 y/o female with a cosmetically concerning mole on her right cheek. It is a raised, skin-colored papule, approximately 4 mm in diameter. The patient reports no change in size, shape, or color of the mole, and it has been present for several years. What would be the most appropriate treatment approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Laser treatment

 

Explanation:

 

Melanocytic nevi:

  • Also called moles. They are proliferating nevus cells derived from the neural crest.
  • Acquired melanocytic nevi are nests of proliferating nevus cells and are classified into three types:
    • Junctional nevi: Present at the dermo-epidermal junction which are small and dark brown.
    • Compound nevi: Present at the dermo-epidermal junction and the dermis as these are slightly raised and lighter in color than junctional nevi.
    • Intradermal nevi: Present in the dermis are raised papules that are either skin-colored or red.
  • Treatment is usually done for cosmetic reasons, if indicative of malignancy, treatment options include electrocautery, laser treatment, and surgical excision.
  • Congenital melanocytic nevi are present at birth. Giant congenital melanocytic nevi (also called bathing trunk/garment nevi) may have malignant potential.
  • Halo nevi presents as a nevus with a halo around it which is caused by the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes surrounding the mole.

 

Option A: Topical corticosteroids are primarily used to reduce inflammation and are not indicated in the treatment of melanocytic nevi.

 

Option B: Oral antibiotics are used for bacterial infections and are not relevant to the treatment of intradermal nevi

 

Option D: While intradermal nevi are benign, watchful waiting is not the most appropriate approach in this case.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with multiple hyperpigmented patches on the skin, as shown in the image below. These patches have been present since early childhood and are more than six in number. Which of the following skin lesions are seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B) Café au lait macules

Explanation:

  • The clinical history and skin findings suggest a diagnosis of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), which is associated with Café au lait macules. 
  • Café au lait macules are hyperpigmented macules with smooth or serrated borders, resembling coffee stains on milk.

  • They are asymptomatic, usually present at birth (congenital), or occur early in life and can occur anywhere on the body, but common in the trunk and extremities.
  • The color varies from light brown to dark brown, ranging from a few millimeters to several centimeters.
  • They may be present as solitary or multiple spots and are sometimes associated with syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1)/ von Recklinghausen’s disease.
    • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2).
    • McCune Albright Syndrome.

Other features associated with NF1: 

  • Optic nerve glioma
  • Lisch nodules (Iris hamartoma)
  • Sphenoid dysplasia (Bare orbit sign)
  • Crowe sign (Axillary, inguinal freckling)
  • Tibial pseudoarthrosis

 

Vitiligo vulgaris (Option A) presents with depigmented, chalky white macules and patches. It is characterized by the absence of melanocytes, leading to the loss of pigmentation.

Freckles (Option C) are lighter brown macules usually seen in sun-exposed areas, especially during summer, due to increased activity of melanocytes with normal melanocyte count. They are typically smaller and lighter in colour than café au lait macules.

Nevus depigmentosus (Option D) presents as a single, hypopigmented macule with stable margins in a dermatomal distribution. It is asymptomatic and congenital, often appearing at birth due to defective transfer of melanosomes to the keratinocytes and remains stable throughout life.

questions.text: A 45-year-old fair-skinned woman presents with multiple tan to dark brown macules on her face and the dorsal aspect of her hands. These macules are 3 to 20 mm in size and have appeared after chronic sun exposure. Which of the following therapeutic options is not indicated for the treatment of these lesions?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: Option C

EXPLANATION:

The patient presented with multiple tan to dark brown macules on her face and the dorsal aspect of her hands. These macules are 3 to 20 mm in size and have appeared after chronic sun exposure which can be diagnosed as solar lentigines

Solar lentigines are benign pigmented skin lesions that occur in response to excessive or chronic sun exposure.

Treatment for solar lentigines is generally unnecessary unless for cosmetic purposes. Therapeutic options include lightening agents, retinoic acid, trichloroacetic acid, cryotherapy, and laser therapy. However, antibiotic therapy is not indicated for the treatment of solar lentigines.

Cryotherapy involves using extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissues such as solar lentigines. It works by freezing the affected area, leading to cellular destruction and subsequent sloughing off of the lesion.

Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is used for chemical peels and treating conditions like solar lentigines. It induces controlled skin injury, leading to exfoliation and skin regeneration. TCA effectively removes superficial skin layers, including pigmented lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the role of melanosomes in determining skin pigmentation?

choices.text: An increased number of melanocytes causes darker skin pigmentation.
Larger melanosomes are found in individuals with lighter skin tones.
The degradation rate of melanosomes is same across different skin types.
The arrangement of melanosomes influences skin pigmentation.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D

 

Explanation:

 

  • Size of melanosomes influences their arrangement within keratinocytes, which in turn affects skin pigmentation.
  • Larger melanosomes, observed in darker skin tones, are typically dispersed individually.

 

Melanin Types and Production:

  • Two main types:
    • Eumelanin: Brownish-black, responsible for darker skin tones.
    • Pheomelanin: Orangish-red, found in lighter skin tones.
  • Synthesis process (Melanogenesis):

 

  • Melanosomes:
    • Melanin is stored within specialized organelles called melanosomes, which are produced by melanocytes.
    • Size and Distribution:
      • Darker skin: Larger melanosomes (Option A)
      • Lighter skin: Smaller melanosomes (Option B)
    • Degradation: (Option C)
      • Varies between skin types.
      • Lighter skin: Melanosome complexes show degradative changes due to lysosomal enzymes.
      • Darker skin: Larger melanosomes can remain intact up to the stratum corneum.
  • Melanin and Skin Color:
    • Key factors: Type of melanin, Melanosome size, Melanosome distribution (dispersed vs. aggregated),
    • Skin color is NOT solely determined by the number of melanocytes.
  • Regulation of Pigmentation:
    • UV radiation
    • Hormones: Estrogens - increase pigmentation; Melanocortins - melanin production.
